art73: • Subjects on which Parliament has power to make laws (Union List + Concurrent List + Residuary)
• Rights, authority, jurisdiction exercised before Constitution by Government of India
**Clause (2)**: Extends to exercise of rights, authority, jurisdiction outside India to extent vested in Government of India
art162: State executive power extends to subjects on which State Legislature has power to make laws (State List + Concurrent List)
**Subject to**: Union executive power (Art 73) and any directions by Union under Constitution
**Subordinate to Union**: State executive power subject to Union executive power
parallelism: **Union executive**: Extends to Union List + Concurrent List + Residuary subjects
**State executive**: Extends to State List + Concurrent List subjects
**Overlap on Concurrent**: Both have executive power on Concurrent subjects
unionSupremacy: **Art 162 expressly subordinates State executive to Union executive**
**Union can give directions**: Union can give directions to States on executive matters (Art 256, 257)
**State must comply**: States bound to comply with Union's directions
**Failure to comply**: Can lead to President's Rule (Art 356)
exceptions: **Railways**: Entry 22 Union List (legislative) → But Art 258A allows delegation to States
**Defence**: Entry 1 Union List → Union exclusive executive power
**Foreign Affairs**: Entry 10 Union List → Union exclusive executive power
**Inter-state subjects**: Where coordination needed, Union has overriding power
content.examTips: **Art 73**: Union executive extends to Union + Concurrent + Residuary. **Art 162**: State executive extends to State + Concurrent; **BUT subject to Union** (Art 73, Art 256-257 directions). Shows **Union supremacy** in executive sphere. Executive power generally follows legislative power.

articles.title: Art 256 - State Shall Comply with Union Laws

provision: **Art 256**: Executive power of **State** shall be exercised to ensure **compliance with Union laws**
**Mandatory compliance**: States MUST comply with laws made by Parliament
**Applies to all Union laws**: Laws on Union List, Concurrent List, Residuary subjects
**Union can give directions**: Union may give directions to State for compliance
scopeOfDirections: **What directions?**: How State should exercise its executive power to comply with Union laws
• Implementation of Union laws (e.g., GST collection, central schemes)
• Enforcement of Union laws (e.g., criminal laws on Concurrent List)
• Coordination with Centre (e.g., national security, disaster management)
• Use of state machinery for Union purposes
failureToComply: **Art 365**: If State fails to comply with or give effect to Union directions → Union can invoke **Art 356** (President's Rule)
**Constitutional breakdown**: Non-compliance treated as failure of constitutional machinery in State
**President's Rule**: Centre can dismiss State government and impose President's Rule
**Serious consequence**: Loses State's autonomy; Centre takes over
examplesOfDirections: **COVID-19 pandemic**: Centre gave directions to States on lockdown, masks, vaccination
**GST implementation**: Centre directs States on GST collection, compliance
**National security**: Centre directs States on anti-terrorism measures, border security
**Environmental laws**: Centre directs States to implement air/water pollution control
**Disaster management**: Centre directs States during natural disasters, floods, earthquakes
unionSupremacy: **Shows strong Centre**: States obliged to implement Union laws (even if state disagrees with policy)
**No state autonomy on compliance**: State cannot refuse citing federal autonomy
**Unitary feature**: In unitary countries, subordinate units must comply with central laws; Art 256 similar
**Contrast with federal**: In true federal countries (USA), states have more autonomy; Can challenge federal laws in court
content.examTips: **Art 256**: State MUST **comply with Union laws**. Union can give **directions** to States for compliance. **Failure** → Art 356 (President's Rule) via Art 365. Shows **Union supremacy** - States obliged to implement Union policies. Unitary feature.

articles.title: Art 257 - State Shall Not Impede Union's Exercise of Powers

provision: **Art 257**: Executive power of State shall be exercised so as **NOT to impede or prejudice** exercise of Union's executive power
**Negative obligation**: State shall NOT obstruct Union
**Applies to all Union activities**: Communications, defence, railways, etc.
**Union can give directions**: To ensure State doesn't impede Union
specificProvisions: **Art 257(1)**: General - State shall not impede Union's executive power
**Art 257(2)**: **Communications** (roads, railways, waterways) → Union can give directions to State to construct, maintain specific highways/roads for Union's purposes
**Art 257(3)**: **Railways** → Union can give directions to State for protection of railways and safe working
**Art 257(4)**: Union bears **cost** of compliance with directions under Art 257(2), (3)
art257vs256: **Art 256**: State must **comply with** Union laws (positive obligation - do something)
**Art 257**: State must **not impede** Union (negative obligation - don't obstruct)
**Both show Union supremacy**: Union's executive power paramount
communicationsAndRailways: **Entry 23 Union List**: National highways declared by Parliament
**Art 257(2)**: Union can direct State to construct/maintain roads for Union's purposes (strategic, defence, communication)
**Art 257(3)**: Union can direct State to protect railways, ensure safe railway working
**Cost borne by Union**: Union reimburses State for expenditure incurred in compliance (Art 257(4))
examples: **National highways**: Union directs State to maintain NH passing through State
**Defence roads**: Union directs State to construct roads for defence/strategic purposes
**Railway protection**: Union directs State police to protect railway installations, prevent sabotage
**Railway crossings**: Union directs State to construct over-bridges, under-passes for railway safety
**Strategic corridors**: Union directs State to ensure smooth passage for defence, communication
content.examTips: **Art 257**: State shall **NOT impede** Union's executive power. Special provisions for **communications** (roads) and **railways** (Art 257(2), (3)). Union can give directions; **Union bears cost** (Art 257(4)). Ensures Union's functions not obstructed by States.

articles.title: Art 355 - Union's Duty to Protect States

provision: **Art 355**: It shall be the **duty of the Union** to:
• Protect every State against **external aggression** and **internal disturbance**
• Ensure that government of every State is carried on in accordance with **provisions of Constitution**
**Duty, not power**: Framed as Union's duty; But implies power to intervene
protectionAgainstExternal: **External aggression**: War, invasion, armed attack by foreign country
**Union's role**: Defence is Union subject (Entry 1 Union List)
**Armed forces**: Union deploys armed forces to protect State
**No state consent needed**: Union's duty; State cannot refuse protection
**Emergency**: If external aggression, Union can declare National Emergency (Art 352)
protectionAgainstInternal: **Internal disturbance**: Armed rebellion, large-scale violence, breakdown of law and order
**Union's intervention**: Union can send armed forces (Art 355) or impose President's Rule (Art 356)
**State request**: Usually State requests Centre's help; But Centre can intervene suo motu if needed
**Examples**: Naxal violence, insurgency, terrorism, communal riots
constitutionalGovernance: **Ensure constitutional governance**: Union must ensure State government functions according to Constitution
**Basis for Art 356**: If State government cannot function constitutionally → Art 356 (President's Rule)
**Constitutional breakdown**: Union can intervene to restore constitutional governance
**Prevents unconstitutional actions**: State cannot act against Constitution; Union intervenes
art355vsArt356: **Art 355**: Union's **duty** to protect States and ensure constitutional governance
**Art 356**: Union's **power** to impose President's Rule if constitutional machinery fails
**Connection**: Art 355 provides duty/rationale; Art 356 provides mechanism/power
**Art 355 wider**: Includes external aggression, internal disturbance (not just constitutional failure)
examplesOfUse: **1962 China war**: Union protected border states (external aggression)
**1971 Bangladesh war**: Union protected eastern border (external aggression)
**Naxal violence**: Centre deploys CRPF, armed forces to States (internal disturbance)
**Punjab terrorism (1980s)**: Centre intervened under Art 355, later Art 356
**Kashmir insurgency**: Continuous deployment of armed forces (internal disturbance)
content.examTips: **Art 355**: Union's **duty** to protect States against **external aggression + internal disturbance** and ensure **constitutional governance**. Basis for Union's intervention in States. Connection with **Art 356** (President's Rule). Shows Union's paramount role in protecting States.

provision: **Art 356**: If President, on receiving **Governor's report** or otherwise, is satisfied that government of State **cannot be carried on in accordance with Constitution** → President can declare **emergency in that State**
**Effect**: State government dismissed; State Legislature dissolved/suspended; President rules State through Governor; Parliament makes laws for State
**Called**: President's Rule, State Emergency, Constitutional Emergency
procedure: **Step 1**: Governor sends report to President that constitutional machinery failed in State
**Step 3**: Proclamation must be laid before **Parliament** within 2 months
**Step 4**: Approved by both Houses by **simple majority** within 2 months
**Step 5**: If approved, continues for **6 months**; Can be extended up to **3 years** (max)
duration: **Extensions**: Can be extended by 6 months at a time
**Maximum**: **3 years** total (originally 1 year; 44th Amendment made it 1 year; But multiple extensions possible up to 3 years)
• **Election Commission certifies** that elections cannot be held in State due to difficulties
consequences: **State government dismissed**: Chief Minister and Council of Ministers resign/removed
**State Legislature**: Can be dissolved or kept in suspended animation
**Governor rules**: Governor administers State on behalf of President
**Parliament legislates**: Parliament can make laws for State (on State List subjects) - Art 250 NOT applicable; Separate power under Art 356
**President's powers**: President exercises all powers of State government and Governor
groundsForImposition: **Constitutional breakdown**: Government cannot be carried on according to Constitution (Art 356 language)
• Hung Assembly - No party has majority
• Chief Minister loses majority, refuses to resign
misuse: **Most controversial provision**: Used 125+ times; Often misused for political reasons
• 1959 Kerala - First time; Communist govt dismissed (political)
• 1977-79 - Janata govt dismissed 9 Congress-ruled states (political revenge)
**Centre dismissing Opposition-ruled states**: Pattern of misuse when Centre and State have different parties
srBommaiCase: **S.R. Bommai v Union of India (1994)** - Landmark 9-judge bench
**Facts**: BJP govts in Rajasthan, MP, HP, UP dismissed using Art 356 (1992); Challenged in SC
• **Federalism is basic structure**: Cannot be arbitrarily destroyed via Art 356
• **President's satisfaction justiciable**: Courts can examine whether material existed for President's satisfaction
• **Governor's report not binding**: President must independently assess; Courts can see Governor's report
• **Floor test mandatory**: If dispute about majority, must prove on floor of Assembly (not dismiss without floor test)
• **Parliament's approval justiciable**: Courts can examine whether Parliament's approval valid
**Effect**: Curbed Art 356 misuse significantly; Post-1994, much less frequent use
44thAmendmentSafeguards: • Initially 1 year duration (can be extended up to 3 years with conditions)
• Extension beyond 1 year needs: National Emergency OR EC certification that elections cannot be held
• Parliament's approval needed within 2 months (both Houses)
**Before 44th Amendment**: Could be extended indefinitely; More arbitrary
content.examTips: **Art 356**: President's Rule if **constitutional machinery fails** in State. Governor's report → President's proclamation → Parliament approval (2 months) → 6 months duration (extendable to 3 years max). **Most controversial** provision - Misused 125+ times. **S.R. Bommai (1994)**: Federalism is basic structure; Floor test mandatory; Justiciable. **44th Amendment**: Safeguards added. Post-Bommai, less misuse.

articles.title: All India Services - Union's Control over State Administration

provision: **Art 312**: **Rajya Sabha** can create **All India Services** (AIS) by resolution passed by **2/3rd majority**
**Currently 3 AIS**: Indian Administrative Service (IAS), Indian Police Service (IPS), Indian Forest Service (IFS)
**Dual control**: AIS officers serve both Union and States; Recruited by Union, serve in States, controlled by Union
**Unitary feature**: Shows Union's control over State administration
whyRajyaSabha: **States' consent**: Through RS, States authorize creation of AIS
**2/3rd majority**: Ensures broad consensus; Not simple majority
**Federal spirit**: States voluntarily agree to Union-controlled services in their administration
threeServices: • Created: 1947 (successor to ICS - Indian Civil Service)
• Functions: District Collector, Chief Secretary, Secretaries in Union/State govts
• Functions: DGP, IGP, SP, Police Commissioners, CBI, IB, RAW
• Functions: Forest conservation, wildlife protection, environment
• Panchayat Forest Officers, Chief Conservator of Forests
dualControl: **Recruitment**: Union Public Service Commission (UPSC) conducts Civil Services Exam; Union recruits
**Cadre**: Officers allocated to different State cadres; Serve in States
**Service conditions**: Determined by Union (Parliament makes law - AIS Act 1951)
**Transfers**: Intra-state transfers by State; Inter-state transfers by Union (with State concurrence)
**Disciplinary action**: Major penalties by Union; Minor penalties by State
**Union can recall**: Officers can be deputed to Central government anytime
advantages: **National integration**: Officers from different states serve across India; Promotes unity
**Uniformity**: Uniform standards of administration across states
**Continuity**: Professional, non-partisan administration; Insulated from political pressures
**Coordination**: Better Centre-State coordination (officers understand both perspectives)
**Expertise**: Central training (LBSNAA for IAS, SVPNPA for IPS); High quality
criticisms: **Violates federalism**: Union control over State administration; States have less autonomy
**Centre's agents**: AIS officers may prioritize Union's agenda over State's interests
**States want control**: Many States demand state civil services instead of AIS
**Inflexible**: States cannot remove or discipline officers easily
**Second ARC**: Recommended review of AIS system; States seek more control
constitutionalBasis: **Art 312(3)**: AIS Act regulates recruitment, service conditions
**Art 309**: Parliament/State Legislature can regulate recruitment and service conditions (general provision)
**Proviso to Art 312(3)**: AIS Act overrides Art 309 for AIS officers
content.examTips: **Art 312**: **Rajya Sabha** (2/3 majority) can create **All India Services**. Currently **3 AIS**: IAS, IPS, IFS. **Dual control**: Recruited by Union (UPSC), serve in States, controlled by Union. Shows **Union's control** over State administration (unitary feature). Advantages: National integration, uniformity, continuity. Criticism: Violates federalism.

art258: **Art 258**: **Union can entrust** its executive functions to **State** (or its officers)
**State's consent**: With consent of State government
• Collection of Union taxes (Income tax, GST)
• Implementation of Union schemes (MGNREGA, PM-KISAN, etc.)
• Enforcement of Union laws (criminal laws on Concurrent List)
• Election duty (State machinery used for Lok Sabha elections)
art258A: **Art 258A**: **State can entrust** its executive functions to **Union** (or its officers)
**Union's consent**: With consent of Union government
**Less common**: States rarely entrust functions to Union (Union already has wide powers)
**Examples**: State may request Union to handle specific matters requiring expertise/resources
cooperativeFederalism: **Mutual delegation**: Shows cooperative federalism - Union and States cooperate
**Flexibility**: Both can entrust functions to each other as needed
**Practical arrangement**: Avoids duplication; Uses existing machinery efficiently
**Consent-based**: Not imposed; Both parties must agree
art258Widespread: **Most common**: Union extensively uses Art 258 to entrust functions to States
• State machinery closer to people (district collectors, police)
• Union lacks field staff in States
• Union schemes implemented through State govts (MGNREGA, PMAY, etc.)
• Tax collection (State helps Union collect taxes)
• Elections (State machinery conducts Lok Sabha elections for Election Commission)
costsAndReimbursement: **Art 258**: Union may entrust **with or without** reimbursing State for extra costs
**In practice**: Union usually reimburses States for costs incurred
**Examples**: Election expenses (Union reimburses States), Scheme implementation (Union funds + State implementation)
**Dispute**: Sometimes States complain Union doesn't adequately compensate
content.examTips: **Art 258**: Union can **entrust** functions to State (with consent). **Art 258A**: State can entrust to Union (with consent). Shows **cooperative federalism**. Art 258 widely used (Union schemes, tax collection, elections via State machinery). Union may/may not reimburse costs. Practical cooperation mechanism.

art131: **Art 131**: Supreme Court's **original jurisdiction** for disputes between:
**Exclusive jurisdiction**: Only SC can decide such disputes (not High Courts)
**Legal disputes**: Must involve legal questions of interpretation of Constitution/laws
**Examples**: Border disputes, river water sharing, taxation disputes
art262: **Art 262**: Parliament can make law for adjudication of **inter-state river water disputes**
**Clause (1)**: Parliament may provide for adjudication of disputes regarding use, distribution, control of inter-state river waters
**Clause (2)**: Parliament may exclude SC/HC jurisdiction over such disputes
**Inter-State Water Disputes Act 1956**: Parliament enacted under Art 262
**Tribunals**: Central government constitutes tribunal for each river water dispute (e.g., Cauvery, Krishna, Ravi-Beas)
riverWaterDisputes: **Most contentious inter-state disputes**: Water sharing (Cauvery, Krishna, Godavari, Ravi-Beas, Narmada, etc.)
**Why contentious?**: Water is critical for agriculture, drinking, industries; Scarcity leads to conflicts
**Tribunal process**: State approaches Centre → Centre constitutes tribunal → Tribunal hears, adjudicates → Award binding
• **Cauvery dispute**: Karnataka vs Tamil Nadu (decades-long; Supreme Court finally settled 2018)
**SC role**: Though Art 262(2) excludes SC jurisdiction, SC entertains appeals under Art 136 (Special Leave Petition)
art263: **Art 263**: **Inter-State Council** - To investigate and advise on inter-state disputes
**President can establish**: Inter-State Council if public interest requires
• Inquire into and advise on disputes between States
• Investigate and discuss subjects of common interest (Centre-State, State-State)
**Not a tribunal**: Only advisory body; Recommendations not binding
interStateCouncil: **Composition**: PM (Chairman), CMs of all States, Governors of UTs, 6 Union Cabinet Ministers (nominated by PM)
**Functions**: Discuss Centre-State and inter-state issues; Coordinate policies; Resolve conflicts amicably
**Meetings**: Rarely meets regularly; Not very effective in practice
**Sarkaria Commission (1988)**: Recommended permanent Inter-State Council for better Centre-State relations
otherDisputes: **Resolved by**: SC under Art 131 OR Parliament by law (Art 3 - reorganization)
**Taxation disputes**: GST disputes resolved by GST Council
**Political disputes**: Resolved through negotiations, political process, Inter-State Council
content.examTips: **Art 131**: SC's original jurisdiction for Union-State, State-State disputes. **Art 262**: Inter-state river water disputes → Parliament makes law (Tribunals); SC/HC jurisdiction can be excluded. **Art 263**: Inter-State Council (advisory). Most contentious disputes: **River water** (Cauvery, Krishna). **Inter-State Council** established 1990 (Sarkaria Commission).

data.summary: **Centre-State Administrative Relations**: **Art 73**: Union executive extends to Union + Concurrent + Residuary subjects. **Art 162**: State executive extends to State + Concurrent; **Subject to Union**. **Centre's Directions**: Art 256 (Comply with Union laws), Art 257 (Not impede Union), Art 355 (Union's duty to protect States). **President's Rule** (Art 356): Most controversial provision; Misused 125+ times; **S.R. Bommai (1994)** curbed misuse (federalism is basic structure, floor test mandatory, justiciable). **All India Services** (Art 312): IAS, IPS, IFS - Dual control; Shows Union's control over State administration. **Delegation**: Art 258 (Union entrusts to State - widely used), Art 258A (State entrusts to Union). **Inter-State Disputes**: Art 131 (SC jurisdiction), Art 262 (River water tribunals), Art 263 (Inter-State Council). Shows **strong Union executive control** over States.
